Comments_List: amazing overview on IPE literature and methodology

I learned the basic issues and approaches in cutting-edge international political economy studies. I also learned how to take a deep dive into political economy papers and critically evaluate authors' claims.

I learned an immense amount about substantive topics in IPE. I also benefited from the in-depth discussion about methodologies underpinning both contemporary and more foundational works in the subfield.

The course presentations forced students to grapple with the nuances and particulars of each paper.
Strengths: very detailed discussion of papers, including methods; very engaged professor

The course allowed students to present on select papers, which facilitated deep engagement with each paper, and to take a step back to synthesize the knowledge through reading response papers. The course was excellent for both content mastery and methodological learning. One thing I wished there was more of was Professor Queralt's take on matters, or lecture-style synopsis of the way he interprets the topic or question at hand.

Strengths:

-- intensive discussion regarding the articles and methods was particularly beneficial

-- professor was quite engaging and provided extensive feedback on our criticisms/comments on the course readings. It was quite clear that he came prepared to have an in-depth discussion of each reading.

Weaknesses:

-- the small class size made the regular student presentations a bit intense in the middle of the semester, but overall, that requirement was beneficial

-- wish we'd engaged with more book-length scholarship on IPE to see how political scientists craft and explore questions in a more in-depth, lengthier format
Absolutely, to anyone who is interested in political economy or international relations.
Definitely; there's much to learn substantively about IPE and cutting edge research in political science more generally.
